1.title: Whispering Void (191 hymns: Creation, invocations to Agni/Indra/Varuna)

1.1.sanskrit: agnim īḷe purohitam yajñasya devam ṛtvijam | hotāraṃ ratnadhātamam ||
1.1.translation: I laud Agni, the chosen Priest, God, minister of sacrifice, / The herald, lavishest of wealth. / Wise master of the sacrifice, / The true, the universal God. / All hail to this our sacrifice! / May he, the bright, the wondrous God, / Accept our offering as it is.
1.1.explanation: The Rigveda's opening hymn invokes Agni as the ritual fire and divine messenger, bridging humans and gods in yajna (sacrifice); it sets the tone for Vedic devotion, like lighting a candle to connect with the universe's energy.

1.2.sanskrit: vāyoṃ śūcīnā śucayo na ā gahi | śūcībhiraśvasā sajoṣāsaḥ ||
1.2.translation: Come, Vayu, pure, to the pure, / With pure steeds, pure, come to us, / Come with thy thousand, come with thy ten thousand. / Come, Vayu, to the gifts we offer.
1.2.explanation: Praise to Vayu (wind god) for his swift, purifying presence in rituals; emphasizes purity and speed in divine approach, akin to fresh air clearing mental fog in modern mindfulness.

1.3.sanskrit: aśvinaṃ vājinīvasū devāv adya havāmaha | yuvor havyaṃ ghṛtācī ||
1.3.translation: We call today the Ashvins, rich in steeds, / Gods whose offering is anointed with ghee.
1.3.explanation: Invocation to the Ashvins, divine physicians and bringers of healing; represents early recognition of medicine's divine aspect in restoring wholeness.

1.4.sanskrit: indraṃ mitraṃ varuṇam agnim āhur atho divyaḥ sa suparṇo gharutmān | ekaṃ sad viprā bahudhā vadanty agniṃ yamaṃ mātariśvānam āhuḥ ||
1.4.translation: They call him Indra, Mitra, Varuna, Agni, / And he is heavenly nobly-winged Garutman. / To what is One, sages give many a title: / They call it Agni, Yama, Matarisvan.
1.4.explanation: Early philosophical insight recognizing unity in divine diversity; prefigures the Upanishadic concept of Brahman as the singular reality behind multiple manifestations.

1.5.sanskrit: tvaṣṭāraṃ vṛṣaṇaṃ havāmahe 'sya patnīṃ suvarcasam | yayor devā anūṣata ||
1.5.translation: We call Tvashtr, the strong, whose spouse is glorious, / Whom the gods follow.
1.5.explanation: Invocation to Tvashtr, the divine artisan and shaper of forms; represents the creative principle that gives distinctive form to all beings.

1.6.sanskrit: indra jyeṣṭhaṃ varuṇa tvaṣṭar dyaur bṛhaspatir viśvakarmā marudgaṇaḥ | sarasvatī svarṇara ā pṛthivyā adite mitrāvaruṇāv imaṃ huve ||
1.6.translation: Indra the chief, Varuna, Tvashtr, Heaven, / Brihaspati, Vishvakarman, Marut host, / Sarasvati, the Sun, Earth and Aditi, / Mitra and Varuna, these I call.
1.6.explanation: Comprehensive invocation of multiple deities, showing the Vedic pantheon's breadth and the ritual practice of inviting all relevant powers to the sacrifice.

1.7.sanskrit: indraṃ vocaṃ pūrvyāṇāṃ śaviṣṭhaṃ śūraṃ satpatiṃ | yaḥ pṛthivīṃ vy amuñcad dhiraṇyayīm ||
1.7.translation: I sing of Indra, mightiest of the mighty, / Hero, true lord, who freed the golden earth.
1.7.explanation: Praise of Indra's heroic deeds, particularly his role in ordering the cosmos by freeing the earth; establishes him as the paradigmatic divine warrior.

1.8.sanskrit: indraṃ naro nemadhitā havante indraṃ somasya pītaye vṛṣāya | indraṃ viprāso akrata dhītīr indraṃ kārvo apasaḥ ||
1.8.translation: Men call on Indra, fain for spoil and conquest, / On Indra for the drinking of the Soma; / The sages have prepared their songs for Indra, / The priests their sacred duties.
1.8.explanation: Emphasizes Indra's role as the primary recipient of Soma offerings and the focus of priestly invocations for success in earthly and cosmic battles.

1.9.sanskrit: apāṃ napād amṛtasya nābhāv indraṃ somaṃ pibatam asya yonau | tṛṣṇajam bhāgam avase havāmahe ||
1.9.translation: Sons of the Waters, navel of immortality, / Indra and Soma, drink of this in its birthplace; / We call the portion born of thirst for our protection.
1.9.explanation: Mystical identification of Soma with cosmic waters and immortality; shows the sacramental understanding of Soma as connecting mortals to divine realms.

1.10.sanskrit: brahma jajñānaṃ prathamaṃ purastād vī sīmataḥ suruco vena āvat | sa budhnyā upamā asya viṣṭhāḥ satāśca yonim asataśca vī avaḥ ||
1.10.translation: First-born of Order, the vast, the shining, / The sage who measures out the earthly regions; / He knows the highest abode of all beings, / He knows the source of both the Real and Unreal.
1.10.explanation: Philosophical hymn exploring the primordial principle of Order (Rta) as the foundation of both cosmic structure and moral law in the universe.

1.11.sanskrit: tvaṣṭā ha yat tvāṣṭrī vivasa āpaḥ prasravayan nadyaḥ samudram | atiṣṭhan mandrā abhi vācam ukthaiḥ ||
1.11.translation: When Tvashtr, the shaper, sent the flowing waters, / The rivers rushing onward to the ocean, / They stood, rejoicing, with their hymns and praises.
1.11.explanation: Cosmic imagery of rivers flowing to the ocean as emblematic of cosmic order and the shaping power of the divine artisan Tvashtr.

1.12.sanskrit: indraṃ vocaṃ pitaram aśvinedaṃ hiraṇyaretasaṃ dhiṣaṇāyā indram | yaḥ pūrvyāṇāṃ pathyā anv aicchat ||
1.12.translation: I sing of Indra, father of the Ashvins, / Golden-germed, lord of thought and wisdom, / Who found the paths that ancient ones had trodden.
1.12.explanation: Praise of Indra as both cosmic pioneer who discovers ancient paths and as source of divine powers like the Ashvins; shows his multifaceted nature.

1.13.sanskrit: indraṃ mitraṃ varuṇam agnim āhur devaṃ sa viṣṇuṃ sūryaṃ brahmaṇas patim | ṛtaṃ bṛhantam atharvaṇo arcanti ||
1.13.translation: They call him Indra, Mitra, Varuna, Agni, / And he is heavenly Vishnu, Surya, Brahmanaspati; / The Atharvans praise the vast and mighty Order.
1.13.explanation: Continues the theme of divine unity in multiplicity, specifically mentioning Vishnu's rising importance and the Atharvan priests' role in maintaining cosmic order.

1.14.sanskrit: indraṃ vardhanto apturaḥ kṣiyanto vi rājatha | dhiyaṃ dheṣṭa somapāvane ||
1.14.translation: Strengthening Indra, ever-conquering, ruling widely, / Establish wisdom, O Soma-drinkers.
1.14.explanation: Connection between ritual practice (Soma drinking) and the cultivation of wisdom; suggests intoxication as a means to higher consciousness.

1.15.sanskrit: indraṃ vocaṃ vṛṣabhaṃ jātavedasaṃ hiraṇyadaṃ divyaṃ sānum aśvinam | yaḥ pūrvyebhiḥ pathibhiḥ pāti ṛṇā ||
1.15.translation: I sing of Indra, bull, all-knowing, / Golden-giver, heavenly summit, Ashvin-like, / Who protects with ancient paths from debt.
1.15.explanation: Metaphorical language portraying Indra as both cosmic principle and personal protector, using financial imagery (debt) for spiritual obligations.

1.16.translation: Indra indeed has given to his worshippers / Thousands of spoils, abundant wealth; / Who gives to the constant ones riches and gold, / And protects their cattle.
1.16.explanation: Emphasis on Indra as generous patron who rewards faithful worship with material prosperity, particularly the crucial wealth of cattle in Vedic society.

1.17.explanation: Simple, direct invocation showing the practical, economic dimension of Vedic worship and the understanding of divinity as source of material success.

1.190.sanskrit: indraṃ vayam mahādhana indraṃ dhanasya sātaye | havāmahe janā iva ||
1.190.translation: Indra we call for great wealth, / Indra for winning of riches, / As people call for a leader.
1.190.explanation: Continues the established pattern of collective invocation.

1.191.sanskrit: indra id dha nu me jaritṛbhyo 'vīrad vājān sahasriṇah | yaḥ śaśvadbhyo dhanaṃ dāśad dhiraṇyaṃ goṣu rakṣati ||
1.191.translation: Indra indeed has given to his worshippers / Thousands of spoils, abundant wealth; / Who gives to the constant ones riches and gold, / And protects their cattle.
1.191.explanation: Final hymn of Mandala 1, completing the cycle of repetitive invocation and establishing the foundational pattern for the entire Rigveda.
